div.head: THE NATIVE PRESS.
div.p: We, have frequently criticised the political view* of the Nationalist Press, and, we believe, in a tone marked by moderation and an absence of personal warmth. We hare, whih differing from them in all general question*, at times recognised that they had a certaii justification for their criticisms of details oi governmental administration. The persons attacks often made on British official* in theii column* do not appear to call for noleni expressions of resentment or annoyance. The difference in ideas, in habits, in training, and modea uf thought between them and their native critics are au profound that uii*ur«. standings are inevitable, and we outsider tlu'. nothing ii to be gained by taking persona) attack* on British oftrial* "au grand ntrinu. We are, in fact, greatly^ diverted by "Al Mnayad'*'' "muddied oaf*" and their attends/!', hound*, we smile when the Adviser to the Ministry uf Education ia described ia a vtrauge jargon aa "miserable Deniope" and when the advocacy uf his. assassination by a perfervid orator from the secondary schools ir solemnly chronicled by an editor, who baa perbaye taught young Mobamed or Tahir the sounding periods which be aunt* during the storm and stress of a student*' strike.

But when native official* whose auie crime their inability to tee eye to eye with Muatapba Paaha Kamel and hii fallowing in all political matters, are attacked with the moat vulgar personal abuse, we feel a disgust which require* expression. A* an instance what we mean we should like to cite an article entitled 'The Fehmy Excursion, " which appeared in the "Minbar'' of the 21st insL This artiete, which, we shall not advertise unnecessarily by quoting verbatim, contains an eatremely uogrntle- manty reference to tbe Prime Minister's ooo- tiluUonal delicacy, sod is concluded by an ode not over-remarkable for good taste We cannot understand how writers wbo adopt a loftily patriotic tone in their literary pr. ductiona can descend to the extraordinary ungenUemanlineas of attacks of this character a man whose old age and bUmeleas personal character should have been sufficient, had his position in the State failed, to guard him from personal insult. But perhaps there is no possibility of checking the resurgence, in the moat patriotic Egyptians, of an almost barbaric coarseness in abuae, though it range that the editors of "Al Minbar1 should have allowed their journal to coatein a passage which no person of gentlemanly instincts could have written. Surely the Nationalist party does not gain in dignity from these displays of personal spite which, so far from alarming the foreign observer, merely cause him to (hake his head at their bad teste and wonder whether there ia any truth in the proverb, "II Maori yekhaf wa ma yekhtishish." (The Egyptian lean but know* not respect.)

div.head: THE PORTE AND THE GREEK PATRIARCHATE.
div.p: During the last few weeks the Greek Patriarchate ha* been making preparations to hold an (Ecumenical Council of the Orthodox Church in Constantinople, and invitations to send representatives have been addreated to the Churches in Syria, Egypt, and elsewhere. The project has, the •'Time*' Command nopie apindent itatea, now (alien through in consequence of the opposition of the Porte. One of the objects uf bolding the —wii was to consider the question of the Bulgarian schism, and there can be little doubt that the Greek ecclesiastic* intended to try to induce their fellow-Churchmen to adopt an extreme anti- Bulgarian attitude. Tbi* would have been embarrassing to th8 Turkish Government, which, in any case, had no desire to see the council assemble. The Grand Vixior, therefore, took steps which have mode it imposuibie for the council to be held.

From this and other incidents it is thought that the Porte is beginning to lose patience with the Patriarchate. The support which the Greek Bishops of Macedonia cootinue to give the Greek bands, and which it now the greatest obstacle in the way of the restoration of tranquillity,has been too pronounced for the Turks to tolerate it, and the action of the Synod in electing as one of its members the Metropolitan of Grevena, who is accused by the Porte of complicity in the outrages of thg bands, ha* given especial offence to the Grand Vixier. It is by no means impossible that the effect of all this may bate produce s change the Turkish attitude towards the Bulga- ,n Exarchate. "Indeed," says the correspondent, "I hear that the .Exarch may be allowed to act upon the rights which were loog ago conferred upon him by Imperial firman, but which he has hitherto been preen ted from enjoying. It is possible that some arrangement of this sort was made at the interview which Nejib Melhame had with Prince Ferdinand in the autumn. Nothing would contribute more effectively to improvement than such a change of attitude of the Po^te towards the Bulgarian national Church "A now believed to be imminent."

'Although the idea of holding sn (Ecumeni- cal Council has proved abortive, it is not without interest to note that there was a desire on the part of some Greek prelate* to raise the question of s union of the Orthodox and Anglican Churches. English clerical tourists bo have visited Constantinople and have taken the opportunity to pay their respects to the Greek Patriarch and other ecclesiastical dignitaries ha vecontrived to give the impression hat there exists a strong feeling in England in favour o' this somewhat chimerical project. Naturally enough, Greek Churchmen would hare been glad to try to exploit this feeling forthe benefit of the Greek cause in Macedonia

div.head: MINIEH AGRICULTURAL SHOW
div.p: OPENING CEREMONY TO-DAY.
(PROM OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT.)
Minieh, Thursday.

The opening of the Agricoltural Show, held under the so-pices of the Khedivial Agricoltu ral Society, took place this morning in the presence of a large gathering. Among those present were T. H. Prince Hussein Pasha- Kame' (who is presi'ent of the society) and Prince Omar Pasha Tonsoar, Mr. P. W. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Inte rior, Mr. Dunlop, Adviser to the Ministry of Bduostion, the moadirs of Upper Egypt, the members of the executive committee of the society, and a large master of the leading notables in Minieh and the neighbourhood.

The show ground adjoins the moudirich and is ten feddana in extent. The show itself is a great succes. There is a very fine display of grain and the magnificent exhibits of wheat are the beat which have ever been sent to any, of the society's h w. The cotton exhibitare good for the district, but are naturally inferior to there obtainable in Lower Eyot. There are about 250 horses on how and their quality is good. The donkeys are splendid, as are also the camels. Many exhibits of local industries are being shown.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: This morning the Khediva received the new German Diplomatic Agent, Count Bernadorff who presented his credentials with the anal ceremony at Abdeen Palace.
His Highness will attend Friday prayers to morrow at the Morque of E Husseini.
The Khedive has sent Ali Bey Sh-bin, his techri fatebi, to erquire after the health of Ali Asghar Khan, Persian Diplomatic Arent, who has gone for a change of air to Mena House.

div.head: THE STATE BANK SCHEME.
div.p: The first meeting of the committee selected at the last meeting of the board of the Nation al Bank held on Monday last under the presi dency of the Governor, will be he'd to-day. The committes consists of Mr. Rat hael Suares, Mr. Ambroise Zervadachi, Mr. Role, of Alex andria, and Harari Pasha. The committee has been appointed to study the proposals made by the Government on the subject of the State Bank and to consider the changes that will have to be made in the tatutes and the new by-laws that will have to be drawn up so as to supply Egypt with an institution conforming to the standard of a State Bank, making allowances for local conditions. The committee will keep the board informed of the nature and extent of the Government's proposals, while at the same time advancing the negotiations in matters of detail.
Corporation of Western Egypt.
A farther supply of some 1,260 tons of permanent way material have been despatched for nee in the construction of the Western ORA Railway.
State Railway Institute.

We are asked to state that the members of the Egyptian State Railway Institute will be "at home" to the sergeants and lady friends of the Lancashire Fa-iliers, prior of their depar tore from this country, on Saturday evening, 1st December. Members and friends are invited.
Canal Navigation.

All the canals in the First Circle of Irrigation will be reduced from the 10th December next and navigation will be completely stopped in all navigable canals, except in the Ismailia Canal, from the 15th December. Navigation" in the Ismailia Canal will be available for small boats only.
Erratum.

In our isane of the 26th inst., we ar nonneed that a certain Mahmond Taher had been Arrested on charges of frand. This person is not the M-hmond Taber Haki who is editor of "E Garideh E Ishonish" and to whom we apologian for the error, which arose from the similitude of the two names.
Corman Training Ship.

The German training ship Stach (Captain von Holleben) arrived at Alexandris from Corfa yesterday afternoon. This morning the German Consal and Vice-Consul went on board and anb-equently the Conen! accompanied Captain Hollefen on a visit to H.E. the Gover nor. The vessel will remain here till the 15th proxo.
Suez Canal.
On the 27th November, 14 vessels, 4 north-

ward and 10 southward bound, transited the Canal, and paid transit and passenger toll Fr: 384,832.10. Of these vese's, 8 were British, 4 German. and 2 Dotch. The total revenue since November 1 is Fr. 8 018 507 07. During this period. 287 vesiela transited the Canal, 128 northward and 159 southward bosad
Tour Eiffel Music Hall.

A be fi night in aid of the Soldiers and Sailers Pemilies Ass cistion was given yester day at the new Tour Eff 1 Music Hall, ard med quie pleasant. The programme was want varied and included selections by the band of the R yal Dublin Fusiliers and fencing hopte by members of the local e'eh. There i were beside the anal turns." of which perhaps, the most but ceable were Trewey's, Joggling, Dodola's silhouettes, and Mile Dantes. The American ventriloquist Leo had a good reception.

div.head: ADVANCE HELOUAN!
div.p: IMPROVEMENTS AND PROGRESS.

Helonan is forging ahead this season; and when the Helonan Improvements Co. is in being we may expect to see still farther changes and improvements in this delightful spot. The wonderful alterations in the station of Bab-el Lonk and train service are already being highly appreciated, and the transformation of that dusty little terminus of the Dalta Light Railway Co. reflects great credit on those who have had to do with it. The entire station has been re-decorated and re-arranged. The Khedivial sleon with its private entrance ard ladies' room is now a handsomely furnished suite, and the ladies' rooms, both first and second classe, are furnished with every conve nience and in the best of taste. The rolling stock now includes handeome corridor carriages of Belgian construction, fitted with electric light and wonderfully essy action, all the more wonderful when one remembers the jolting and baking of the old cars.

Many changes are observable in Helonan itself. Varions of the main roads, have been macadam zed and structural alterations and additions have been made at that enormous Sanatorium, "Al Hayat." The little English Church, open last Sunday for the first time this season, now bosats a new flooring of handsome tile. The Grand Hote has been freshly painted, and shows up bravely with its white surroundings. New steam heating apparatus. has been supplied by the Nungovich Co, to all the cabins of the Bath; and an efficient staff of Begi-h trained nurses of both sexes have arrived from Harrogate to carry on the work of massage. Gffing is in fall progress, Mr. Horace Talford, the professional, being already installed at the Grand. The tennis courts at the Tewfik Palace Hotel are also in good working order; and a good staff of riding horses are also at the disposal of the guests at the latter hotel. The Hotel des Bains opens this week; and already there is a very fair collection of visitors in the others. Dr Hobson is back again at the Grand, and Dr. Bentley with his family are again installed in their eld quarter. The Rev. Campbell (English Chaplain) is at the Grand Hotel with Mr. Campbell; and among the other visitors. at the same hotel are the Countess Karolyi and the Countess Garaldine Karolyi (from Bada Perth), Mr. WH Brad'ey with his wife and daughter, Dr. Hilliard, Capt. A. Adams (who is re-ponsible for the improvements in the train service lready mentioned). Mr. P. Hart Dyke, Mr. H. B. Bedford, Lt. Col. A. G. Balfour and Mrs. Balfour, Mrs. Birley, a well known visitor to Helouan, and her son, Mr. F. G. Filde, the Rev. W. N. B. Cooper, and Mrs. H. W. Deniann, whose husband is the U.S.A. Adviser to the Mikado. Among those staying at the Tewfik Palace are Judge Bond, president of the Native Court of Appesl, and Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Coldwelle, the well known traveller and his wife Mr. Coldwell's feats of daring include a journey on foot from Somaliland to the Niger and his hanting prowe's is well known. He is now making arrangements for his third trip up the Blue Nile as far as the Ethiopian frontier. where he hopes to find much shooting. He will be accompanied by his wife, and expects to start on his travels sbont the middle of Desember.

The first H-loan rece meating is advertised for December 28, and is sure to be well attended Arrangements are being made for pigeen shooting in the grounds of the Tewfik Palace) Hotel, which form of sport will also attract not a few.

div.head: HOTEL FIRE AT ASSOUAN.
div.p: A serions fire broke out in the New Continental Hotel at abont half-past reven tonight, due to a cigarette which had been dropped by a visitor who came by the express train to-day and put up at the hotel.

The attention of passers-by was drawn by the loud screams of the people in the hotel ard the fire engine was quickly summoned to the scere. After battling with the fl-mes for more than a couple of hours, the co flsgration was extinguished. but not before a good deal of damage had been done.
The mondir and police officers were conspicuous in their efforts to master the outbreak, and it is in a large measure due to them that it did not assume more serious proportions.

div.head: ST. ANDREW'S DAY.
div.p: To morrow, Fens of St. Andrew, the day of Intercession for Mission, there will be special Fervices at All Saints' Church, Cairo: Holy Commonion, 8.30 a.m.; morning prayer, 10.30 s.m.; evening service, 6.30 p.m. The sermon in the evening will be preached by Rev. C.E. Thomas, LY S.
The following will be the services at St.
Mark's, Alexandris:-
Holy Communion, 8. a m.; morning prayer, 11. a.m.; special service, 6 p.m., as announced last Sunday. There will be collections for the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel.

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
div.p: QUESTION OF FANATICISM.
The following questions were asked in the House of Commons 1st Thersday:-

Mr. Dillon (Mayo, E) asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether his official information still showed that Egypt is in a. dangerons and distorted condition, and affect-. ed by a wave of fanaticism; and, if so, whether he would see that tourists proposing to spend the winter in that country were warned of the danger they might incur.
Sir E Grey.-The situation in Egypt is not now giving rise to special anxiety, and there is no reason, and 1 trust will be none, to discourage people who wish to travel from doing so. (Hear, heat).

Mr. Dillon asked whether the attention of the right hon. gentleman had been drawn to the remarkable fact that fanaticism in Egypt. disappeared when the tourist season commenc ed, and if that did not give him much food for reflection. (Hear, hear).
Sir B. Grey-I cannot say that it gives me mach food for refl-ction. but I do find in it matter for congratulation and satisfaction. (Hear, bear).

div.head: THE DENISHWAI TRIAL
div.p: Mr. Dillon (N. Mayo, Eaat) asked the Poreign Secretary why a fall report of the evidence at the trial of the Denishwai prisoners and of everything that took place in connec tion with that trial had not been supplied to the House in accordance with the promise give by him on the 5th of July last.

Sir E. Grey-The report of the evidence at the trial is not official, but only a summary which was not read over to the witnessss or controlled by the Court. It is substantially the same as the report of the evidence at the preliminary inquiry which has been presented to Parliament, except in some unimportant details. It was not considered necessary to pablish both accounts, and as the account of the evidence given at the preliminary inquiry was regarded as the more accurate of the two, it was decided that it should be published.

Mr. Dillon.-Was the right hon. gentleman's attention drawn to the fact that in the report of the procès verbal the defence was not represented, that there was no possibility of any cross-examination of the witnesses, and that that was not the report promised 1 Sir B. Grey-All I promised was the official report, which has been laid.
Mr. Dillon.-What the right hon. gentleman promised was the report of the evidence of the trial. Not one single line of the evidence has been given.
Sir E. Grey.-I am quite willing to place a copy of the report of the other evidence in the Library. (Hear, hear.)

div.head: EXPLOSIVES IN THE SUEZ CANAL
div.p: Dr. Ratherford asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he was aware that up to the time of the foundering in the Suez Canal of the steamship Chatham, laden with dynamite, no regalations whatever existed for ensuring precautions in the cases of ships passing through the Canal carrying explosives, whether any regulations with the object have since been put in foros; and, it so, whether he will lay upon the table of the House a copy of auch regulations.

Sir Edward Grey-His Majesty's Govern ment are, of course, not responsible for the regulations of the Suez Canal Company. I am informed that steamers carrying explo sives are not prohibited from passing through the Suez Canal, but that the company reserves the right to take such precautions as are usual in all ports. The authorities take no action unless their attention is drawn to a particular ship as having explosives in her eargo.

Such vessels may be berthed at special pointe, and when under transit must fly a special signal, both by day and by night, similar to that shown by petroleum tank steamers. It is obvious that it is to the interest of the company to take every precantion against danger to hfe and property from any source during the navigation of the canal, and the officials have full powers to give directions with this object.

div.head: ARTIN PASHA'S RETIREMENT.
div.p: Mr. J. Robertson (Northumberland, Tyneside) asked for information as to the circumstances in which Yacoub Artin Pasha had retired from the post of Under-Secretary of State for Education in the Beyptian Government and the newly-created office of Secretary of State for Education had been assigned to one of the Judges in the Native Court of Appeal; whether Artin Pa-hs had been promised advancement to the new post on its creation, in ensideration of his great and repeatedly recognized services in promoting educational reforms; and whether the official appointed was without any experience in the work of the department.

Sir B. Gry-It is regretted tha Yacoub Artin Pasha bas considered it necessary to resign. But I cannot admit that he has any grievance against the Ezyptian Government. The appointment of Zagloul Bey as Minister of Public Instruction has been receiv ed with great pleasure and approval by al classes of Egyptian society. There is apparently every prospect that it will inspire confidence in the eenduet of this Department in Egypt, and his personal qualifications for the post are not unlike those which have more than once proved eminently satisfactory in the case of Ministers of Education in this country, who have seldom, if ever, been trained in the Department.

div.head: DEAN BUTCHER'S DEPARTURE.
div.p: MEETING AT BRITISH AGENCY.

At 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon & meeting was held at HB.M's. Agency with Lord Cromer, supported by the American Consul General, in the chair. The object of the meeting was to disocas the presentation of a testimonial to Dean Butoher on his retirement, and we need not say that the British and American colonies were very largely represented.

The proceedings were opened by Lord Cromer, who addressed the meeting as follows: Ladies and Gentlemen,-You all know why we are assembled here this afternoon. The everrolling stream of time has at last brought na to the moment when we must regretfully part from the true friend whom many of us have known for so long. The very high regard and esteem which I entertain for Dean Batcher, my long and intimate personal friendship with him-extending over more than a quarter of a centary-the fact that his departure Break one of the very few remaining links which bind me to the B/yotas it was when I first came into this country-all these con- siderations, and a thousand other memories, some of joy and some of great sorrow, which crowd upon my mind, render it very difficult for me to express to you adequately what I feel on the present occasion. My remarks, therefore, will be very brief. I wieb, however, to say that Dean Butcher has always seemed to me the ideal of a Christian gentleman and of a pastor of the Charch of England. Paithful in all things to the duties and obligations imposed on him by his high mission, unsparing of himselt, wide and tolerant in his views on Church matters, charitable in the most true and Scriptural acceptation of that term, ever ready to console and succour the desolate and oppressed-Dean Batcher has, year by year, week by week, and I might almost say day by day, endeavored, both by precept and example, to lift us above the petty cares and annoyances of our daily life, and to instil into us our duty towards God and our daty towards our neighbour. And let me remind you, gentlemer,-leav ing alone more sacred subjects, on which I dare not dwell,-thst our neighbours in this country consist for the most part of those who are of a different race and oreed to ourselves. I have good reason for knowing that the respect and esteem in which Dean Butcher is held extends to a circle far beyond the Anglican community, and that it is thared by the neighbours of whom I speak, to a greater extent than possibly the Dean, in his great modesty, himselt recognizes. I firmly believe that Dean. Butcher's teaching and example have not been without effect. His influence in this country has been wholly for good. He has never been in any way aracciated with missionary effort; but he has constantly endeavoured to make those of his congregation who occupy reaponsible positions in this country, and on whose conduct the welfare of the population so largely depends, realize how they should live, and how they should die, as Christians; and he has never failed to impress upon them that in the exercise of their duties the Christian moral code should be their constant guide. I need say no more, except that I am convinced that Dean Butcher and the lady who has been his helpmate, and who has so ably seconded! him in his work, will carry away with them, in their retirement, the esteem and aff-otion of everyone in this country with whom they have been brought in contact. I trust that many years of health and usefulness still lie before them. I beg to move that a subscription list be opened with a view to presenting a testimonial to Dean Butcher on the occasion of his approaching departure from Egypt. I should add that the Governor of the National Bank of Egypt has kindly consented to receive the subscriptions, or they may be sent to Mr. Da Boulay, who has consented to act as secretary and treasurer to the fand. I should also add that in my opinion the presentation should take the form of a purse of gold to be disposed of as the Dean thinks fit.

The Hor. L M. Iddings then addressed] the meeting. He said that he was glad to echo Lord Cromer's words and to support the proposal for which he had pleade!. Dean Butcher's virtues had already been praised; he endorsed all that had been said of them, and added that to them were ad led the graces of homoer and learning. The practice of the American church in foreign lands had always been to combine whenever possible with the English church in one congregation. This had been justified by results. When he came to Cairo he had been delighted to find that All Saints' Church was an ideal church where the two congregations might meet. He knew that the American congregation here was very small, but as their representative he could Fay that they agreed with every word that had been said as to Dean Batcher. It gave him great pleasure to second the motion. The motion that a testimonial be presented to Dean Buteber in recognition of his long and devoted services was then put to the meeting and unanimously voted.

Lord Cromer again addressed the meeting. He stated that it would be indeed difficult to choose a successor to Dean Butcher, but that the community required a man who should resembl his predecessor as far as possible. He would like to point out that the stipend of the chaplain of the British Church in Cairo was raised entirely from the voluntary contributions of residents and visitors. It amonnted to £450, and the sum of £250 was paid in addition for the services of a carate. This was! not a large sum, and as the Church Committee had decided to gadt Dean Butcher a pension of £100 a year from the Church fands, the stipend of his successor would not exceed £40 if the contributions of the community emained at the present level. Then there was the question of the appointment of a suocessor. He believed that this was in part at least a matter for the congregation to decide, working of course with the ecclesiastic al anthorities of the English Church. He intended to communicate with the Archbishop of Canterbary on the subject, expressing his views as to the chaplain they required and asking him to find them anch a man. He would wait for a fortnight before sending the letter so that any member of the congregation. who had not been present at the meeting and had any suggestions to offer could commauicate with him on the subject, This be thought would be the best coarse to follow under the circumstances.

Mr Harrison remarked that wisdom did not usually attend a moltitude of enansellors, and spesking for the charch committee he considered that the congregation could not do better than entrust the matter to the Archbishop of Canterbury and Lord Cromer. This seemed to bim an ideal arrangement.
The meeting closed at 4.50 p.m., when large number of those who had been present affixed their names to the list of subscribers. The sum of £548 has already been sab- Boribed.

div.head: ABBAS THEATRE, CAIRO.
div.p: A CHILDREN'S OPERA COMPANY.
(FROM OUR THEATRICAL CORRESPONDENT.)

I owe the Khedivial Theatre all gratituds in that they repeated "Manon" and left me free to go to the Abbas to see what the children's company was like. It was quite delicious and I give the complete répertoire, so that others may go and, I think, enjoy it as 1 did:-"Barbier de Seville," Bisir d'Amore" (a most charming light Dzatti), "Educande di Sorrento," "Crispino e Commare," "La Fille da Tambour Major," and "Carmen." "La Sonnam bula" was done last night, and "Pipelé" to night. I don't know "Pipelé" or M. Ferrari, the composer, bat it was not unlike the "Elisir d'A more"-good,ligh' music and not commonplace or exaggerated. First of all, M. Guerra, the director of the company and orchestra, plays the pisno and conducte. He deserves a severe fate; he plays that piano and exaggerates those instraments as if he was Ro-enthal in a concert hall; he seems to lose right of the fact that he is playing for children; it might (as) conducting) be Mancinelli trying his best to catch up his half bar of arrear in the pilgrims' march, or Lamoureux paralysing the hall with an extra fortissimo, except that M. Goerra never takes his eyes off his piano. The voices and acting alike were unique. A pure child's voice is a wonder in itself and a child's acting is not only imitative bat so spontaneous and light-hearted; they all enjoyed themselves, and even "rugged" delightfully at times. Ml'e. Levi seems to be the oldest-abcut 12 or 13, I suppose; and her voice is beyond the rest, more formed, and full of talent. One boy, Maillot, did a recitative and aria which was as good as could be. And a wee girl-she is pat down at 9 years-Bottari by name, showed herself to be the most perfect little actress and singer. The whole house rose at her after her solo in the 3rd act and-best of all-she had all the little mannerisms, the little bow, and the movement of the hand to the conductor for the encore. Barlesi is the comic boy of the troupe, and he has a gift for it. He bas ona delightful passge of arms with the chorus who are all persecuting him. First of all he rolled over and over the stage with another boy, then he eluded them all, and jumped into an empty box! They found him there, lolling in ease and laxary, and pulled him out. Ricciolini, another boy, had more falues and feeling than therest, but not quite their spontaneity and youth. He and Mile Levi are older. They are both children, pretty gracefal children, bat with a touch of the born artiste in them which almost indues comparison with full grown performers-on technical points only; for enjoy ment, they were far above those one hears out here. After the curtain fell thres small boys came on, one after the other, and sang Di quella pira" (from Trovatore ") The first two (they tid it in taras) were serious, bat No. 3, Was comic, with weird cries and heroic capers: then all three came on fogether, and No. 3 encouraged his comra les on the high note by his Cornell-Harvardian yells and "monlinet" gestares. Altogether it was an experience, and I hope this will justify my long expatiation thereon. It was far more amusing than our dear Khedivial Opera; those delicions children gave a certain impression, for all our laughter, with the keen innocence of their voices and acting, which we cannot get from the worthies fished ont at the last moment from Rae cherche midi à 14 heures. One can listen to them instead of "praising with faint dams," which one has to do as a rale for these wellpaid, excellent, hard-working, but so hopelessly inadrquste "trouvailles" whom Those in Power have hitherto supplied (though perhaps thiseason may turn out fairly well)

To conclude, I counsel all-the abonnement system excludes so many that this should be of use to a huge section of Cairenes-to go to the Abbas. And I reiterate the wish that that most esteemed director could be-but, wall, perhaps he may pay some attention to-morrow night, and not hopelessly drown those delicate voices. He is not Mark Hambourg re-editing Chopin, and he is not a hireling in a "benglon:" he should therefore have s me consideration for his company and for the audience.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Archdake Lonis 8-lvstor is expected at Alexandria shortly and will take up his winter quarters at his villa at Ramleb.
Baron and Baroness de Monterquion, who arrived at Port Said on Tuesday by the Khedivial S.S. El Kabira, have proceeded to Cairo.

Captain Arthur M. Parqshar, who has been promoted to the rank of Rear Admiral on the retirement of Vice Admiral William Marrack, will be remembered as the officer who was in command of the battle hip Resowa when the Duke and Durbes of Connaught embarked in ber, four years ago, for Ezypt, to open the Assonan barrage, and went on from Bgypt to India to attend the Delhi Darbar, receiving on the conclusion of the voyage the C.V.O.

Another officer who has received promotion as the result of Admiral Marrack's retirement is Rear Admiral G. C. Langley, a former naval attaché at Washington, who is also known in Beypt. Rear-Admiral Langley saw service at the battle of Tel-el-Kebir and the advance on Zagazig. Besides being mentioned in despatches, and receiving the Egyptian medal, with the Tel-el-Kebir clasp, and the Khedive's bronze atar, he was promoted to be commander.

In the Guards' Memorial Chapel Wellington Barracks, last Wednesday. Major Raymond J. Marker, D.8.0., Coldstream Guards, A.DC to Viscount Kitcheper, was married to Miss Beatrice M.8. Jackson, daughter of Sir Thomas and Lady Jackson, of Standsted, Essex. Bir Thomas Jackson gave his daughter away, and Captain R. A. Markham, Coldstream Guards, acted as best man. The bride was attended by four maids, Mise Dorothy Jackson, Miss Digby, and the Hon. Lettice Digby and Hon. Geraldine Digby, the two little daughters of Lord Digby, the bridegroom's uncle. Her train was carried by two little children, Master Godfrey Lloyd and Miss Mary Lloyd. The officiating clergy were the Rev. C.A Peacock, chaplain of the Goards' Chapel, and the Rev. G. Oak- short, vicar of Stansted. The re eption was held at the Alexandra Hotel, and Major and Mr, Marker left later in the afternoon for Alderbrook, Cranleigh, lent them by Mr. Pandeli Ralli. Lord Kitchener presented the bride with her bouquet, and gave to the bridegroom four silver entrée dishes.
Mr. Robert Williams, F.RI.B.A., has returned to Alexandris from London, accompanied by his daughter, Mrs. Travers Symons.

Recently the Holy Synod of the Kingdom of Greece elected the Archimandrite of the Greek Church in London, Dr. Anthony Paraschis, to be Bishop of Patras; and, this having now obtained Royal sanction, Dr. Paraschis will shortly leave England for Athens, where the solemn ceremony of his episcopal consecration will take place in the cathedral of the Hellenic metropolis.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE.
div.p: (Communication Officielle)
La Délégation Municipale s'est rénnie le 27 novembre 1906, à 4 h. p.m. sons la présidence de S. E le Dr. Schiess Pachs.
Présents: M.M. Ahmed Pacha Yehis, E. Benachi, Mansour Bey Youssef, Baron A. de Menssce, Soliman Bey Abani, Dr. G. Valensin, membres, W. P. Chataway, administrateur, 1. Sedky Bey, secrétaire.
Sur la demande de l'Inspectear Sanitaire, la Délégation proposers à une prochaine séance de la Commission l'ouverture d'un crédit supplémentaire de LE 45, pour travaux de dé- sinfection.

Elle adjage à M. Marco Perpich, plus bas offrant, au prix de LB. 198 les travaux d'empierrement de la rue Cogniard à l'Ibrahimieh. Les fournitures des articles divers néces saires au service du nettoiement, sont adjugés aux différents offranta suivant leur cffre la plas basse.
Les travaux du cimentage d'une pièce d'ean an grand jardin Nooths sont adjogés à M. F. Pizz lante, plus bas offrant, au prix de P.T.12,5 le mètre carré.

La Dé'égation prend note de deux lettres ministérielles du 26 novembre 1906 approu vant les crédits votés par la Commission dans a dernière séance, ainsi que le projet d'arrêté relatif aux dé larations à faire pour les ani- maux et véhicules,

La Dé éga ion, après avoir abordé dans une récédente séanes tenue samedi dernier, les propositions budgétaires de l'administrateur pour l'exercice 1907, continue cet, examen fana la séance de ce jour, et décide d'en re-
mettre l'étude définitive à la prochaine réunion de mardi. La séance est levée à 7 h. p.m.

div.head:
THE PLAGUE AT BEYROUT.
VEXATIOUS QUARANTINE MEASURES.
div.p: In my last communiontion I mentioned, as a foregona conclusion, that a post-mortem exmination was made of the corpse of the plagne. stricken men at Haret Hreik, and I was led into this beliet by the foot of the Sanitary Inspector bee having noted on the billa of bealth the woonrience of a onae of plagan as a positive foot, and not a & suspected ove, although such annotation has always implied, not not only the post-mortem, but also, the fortber oorfirmatory evidence of a bacteriological examination. I now learn that neither the autopsy nor the bacteriological examination has been made. A proposal for antepay is said to bave teen made bot declined with disappro val on the ground that an exhumation of the body might cause a very dangerons propagstion of the fatal germs. I have it, however, from an eminent mediosl authority bere that the one in question was of a very virulent kind, the patient having averombed qusiokly After the initial attack of the dire disease. This case having been followed by no fresh ches the cordon that had been established around the plague-ntricken locality was taken off a few days ago

The cang at Rua Beyrout is said to have bien e m'l{ one having eaded in predy recovery. This fortunately alao, bag besu followed hy so fresh onrn; wherefore the Board of Health, after its weekly smion on Toenday, has ordered the abolition of the mediosl visit bitherto anforcad at all Ottoman ports against arrivals from Beyrout; and a

aniversal rense of relief has been telt at the Jabolition of such restrictions. In this casa also no bacteriological ex mination has been made, and the ples offered that the man refused to submit to the extraction of pas from the buboe lacks every element of seriou mess and plausibility in view of the serions inte in I volved, lodeed this has provoked severe criti cium in higher quarters.

The anthorities, and indeed all the prop'e here, bsve derply resented, and joatly so, the imposition of five days' quarantine by the Beyptian sanitary acthorities against arrivals from Beyroat, more especially as arrivals from Alexandrin, where case of plages are un interrupted were being sohjeeted to only 48 bons' quarantine, and lately to only 24 hours with the real disinfection and deratizstien formalities. One cannot help regarding this mes are as an unwra table set of retalintion.

div.head:
THE EGYPTIAN STANDARD.
TREASON TO THE SULTAN.
div.p: Some comments have been made in high elre em here on the subjaot of the title of Mostapha Poobs Kamel's new daily paper, The Egyptian Standard," wbuch is possidered to be a term smacking of open nedition to the claima of the Sultan sa Buxarsis of Egypt Loyal Ottomans are asking how it is that the

Bayptian Patriot," who obtained his rank sud title from the Baltas), and has always protected most vigorously of his loyalty and devotion to the Calipb, san dare to use sob & seditious title for his newspaper. How, it is maked, does be dare to style his new organ

The Bayptian Standard" when there is no ench political emblem is existence, the only recognised and official standard of Bgypt being the Ottoman ensiga The title is on sidered here to be an attempt to show the Saitan that the aim of the Bryptian National ist Party is not only Anti-Baropean bot sino Anti-Torkish, and that its object is to conple'e y sever the political ties that bind Beypt to the Sublime Porte.

I was talking on the sabjaot only yesterday to a bigb Turkish official who, I know, bas intimate saneations with Yildiz, and he told we that it was considered most probable that the recent fraternization of Mastapha Pasba Kamel with a seation of the advanced Ra diosl party in London slearly proved that the "Patriot" was being infanced by the bitterent enemies of the Baltan in Europe for it was this olique in Eagland who bad slways shown the most fanatie bostility to his Imperial Majesty, and ware unremitting now in their sudeavoors at mischief-making in Macedonia, just as they were in egging on the Greeks to declare war a few years ago. He added that the political siguificance of the choice which Kamel had made for the name of his newspaper was quite well understood here, and that the Porte would not allow the matter to pass opracognised, for such a pretended fervent sabjeet of the Bultan to rise an independent symbol in Bgypt was nothing lers than trosson to the Caliph

Whether these suspicions are correct, I havs no means of judging, but the famoura ofloat on this matter are worth recording. Does Most.pba Pasba Kamal think it worth while I throwing over the Baltas in order to preserve

the friendsbip of his Radioal-Turoophobe partisana in London 1 As a stroke of polioy Kamel may be quite justified in raining the *Bgyptian Standard" as siga of revolt against the pretensions of the Caliph in order to prove to his supporters in London thist his only objest in the welfare of Egypt, and that ha bas no ulterior motives Bo form the Boltan is concerned. Whether Yildiz will be able to make him change the title of his organ I onanot any. At any rate some very highly placed Tarka hera think that they can read between the lines, and angar that the appropriation of a treasonable emblem against the Baltan's 8-23rainty over Bgypt for the title of the new Nationalist nenspaper is an ominone wign that Mustajba Pahs Kemel intends to abandon his servila policy of adalation towards Abdul Hamid. Ia teresting developments may be expected to arise from this incident. Turkoy's Sedan

A strange silence is observed, bat for all that the despatchea received at the Seraskierste contain very serious naws from Yemen, where the Torkish atratagioal position is "hreatened with catastrophe. Part of Feiti Pasha's forces, which had been surrounded, has surrendered to Mahmond Yahya. The Turkish Marshal himself is shat in at Bars, and is menned by famine, communications with Hodeidab being cut off. He appeals for at least twenty thonsand reinforcements. An interesting little brochure by Mr. Viator Moneri, of Cairo and Alexandris, bus lately been published in French, which he describes mm "Brade boonon igne sur le commerce et | la nitontion agrionle de l'Ile de Chypre." Mr. Movaeri de la with his sobj not in apable manner and with a moderation that inspires confidende. He evidently made good use of the time he spest in Cypras this spring. Bonded Stores Wanted.

le dealing with the commercial possibilities of Pamagoats, be urges that the astoral and most praotioal way of rendering the recen barboor improvements at Famagusta, and the new.y doustrated railway from that port to Nioosis and Morphon, At the extreme west of the oso tral plain, of real value, would be the establishment At Famagoats of "Bouded Stores."

This sobema bas for some time past been Tunder discossion, and there seems to be pretty general feeling in its favour among the mersatile community. Bach stores would, no doubt, add greatly to the commareis! importance of the Island, and bring it into closer bosiness relations with the outer world. High Commissioner's Roport.

The annual report for 19036 of his Exoel. lenoy the High Commissioner is another recantly issued pabliastion, and it contains maob of interest to those concorded in Cyprus Jaffairs. It is generally, an encouraging report, Not only does it reord that "Cypros, on the whole, prosperei daring the year 1905-6;" bat it holde ont more than the usual prospect of advancement and progress in the future. The ground for this optimiem restr, inter alia. on the fact that the British Govarnment has promised to ask Parliament to vote a fixed annal grant in sid of the revenge of Cyprus of $50,000 for the next ensuing tbron yests. It may well be hoped that this will, in the words of the report, enable the country to take advantage of any sorplas rayanga after the necessary expenditure for each year has been met."
Hopeful Signa. | Other hopefal signs are the establishment I by the natives of factories, cooperative banks, and local indastries of various kinds.

This improvement, however, lends very | naturally to the presumption that an increme in the price of commodities bas taken and will still further take place. And snob i. indeer the ce. Every year--possibly every half year- an apward movement is recorded in the oost of living. Articles of daily consumption, @ 8., most, bread, egga,obaroon), all shows very marked rise in value, some commodities having increased 200 and 300 per cent in price during the last 4 or 5 years. Rise in Prloes.

The report refers to the high prions now paid for Cyprar ponies and the unfavour able effect this has upon the mounts of the Cyprus polica, who have to find their own hormon. A general rise in wage has followed

M & matter of Dobrve, and both producers apd | labourers as well as merobants have benefited by the expansion of trade. The official oaas is practically the only section of the community which does not sbare in this prosperity, bot, on the contrary, suffers sadly in consequence of it, and the situation for those Bnglish Government officials receiving less than £800 * year most be becoming serious indeed.
